newsitem.title: CANADA: Toronto stocks play catch-up, end 1.7 pct higher.
newsitem.headline: Toronto stocks play catch-up, end 1.7 pct higher.

* Toronto's key index climbed 1.7 percent in light trading by
the end of Wednesday after U.S. Federal Reserve held rates
steady. * Also played catch-up with New York's gains Tuesday.
Toronto's key equities index surged more than 1.7 percent on Wednesday as investors celebrated a decision by the U.S. central bank to hold U.S. short-term interest rates steady.
The Toronto Stock Exchange's 300 Composite Index climbed 111.30 points to end the day at 6549.04, just below the all-time high of 6557 set on June 16.

Market players widely expected the Federal Reserve to keep rates unchanged after a two-day committee meeting, but still breathed a sign of relief, RBC Dominion Securities investment adviser Ira Katzin said.
Trading was modest at 82 million shares worth C$1.6 billion. The 300 Composite Index came close but failed to break its record close of 6550.61 points on June 13.

Investors also pushed Toronto higher in an attempt to match New York's 50-point gain on Tuesday when desks were shut down for the Canada Day holiday, Katzin said. "The Canadian market also played catch-up to the U.S.'s solid performance yesterday."
The Dow Jones Industrial Average also soared 73 points to 7795 on Wednesday.
A trader wondered when the TSE's recent rally would end. "I'm getting nosebleeds off this market but you can't fight the tape," he said.
All Toronto's 14 sub-indexes gained ground, led by media, heavyweight banks, utilities, pipelines and conglomerates.
Advancing issues edged out declining ones 483 to 448 while 277 ended steady.
--- HOT STOCKS ---
* Shares in small oil firm Grad & Walker Energy Corp jumped 2.35 to 13.50 and topped the most actives after Crestar Energy Inc said it agreed to acquire Grad & Walker in a C$336.2 million deal.
Crestar offered Grad & Walker holders C$13.50 in cash or 0.509 Crestar common shares for each Grad & Walker common share.
